body:
fixed. So careless I am. :rofl:
```python
c = tvm.nd.array(numpy.zeros((N, N), dtype = dtype), remote.cpu(0))
```

```shell
[15:24:42] src/codegen/llvm/codegen_llvm.cc:76: set native vector to be 32 for target aarch64
Baseline: 34.950410
```

@tqchen  I'm sorry to trouble you,have two points to add: 
1) If the num_filter of the small conv are not the same:
conv_0 = bn_act_conv(input, 16)
conv_1 = bn_act_conv(input, 32)
conv_2 = bn_act_conv(input, 64)
It can't declare as a group conv simply.
2) If my ops'type are not the same and just share the input?
def fused_op(inpt):
  conv_0 = bn_act_conv(input, 16)
  pool_1 = max_pool(input)
  other_2 = other_layer(intput)
  return concat([conv_0, pool_1, other_2],dim=1)

Hi, @tqchen , a follow up question, what's the difference between TVM and Halide, if TVM can use Hailide's IR,, why don't we just use the whole Halide directly? 
BTW, in Halide, the schedule across many stages is treated as the main challenge, how about tvm, will tvm deal with the long and wide pipeline, and if yes, how?

Thanks!

http://docs.tvmlang.org/faq.html#tvm-s-relation-to-other-ir-dsl-projects  answers the difference from existing projects, including Halide.  In short, we specifically focus on deep learning, and optimize for multiple hardware backends.

As I mentioned in the first post, the major challenge is to make the schedule space complete enough to cover the state of art kernels for hardware back-ends we want to support, specifically gpu and other hardwares. The second challenge is to build the dsl representation to cover things we care about in deep learning(e.g. recurrence). The other issues include the ease of deployment and interpolation.

These challenges are not well addressed by existing frameworks(including Halide) and requires rethink and design of the stack as opposed to simply reuse an existing one.

You can also find that the TVM's IR itself is evolving, and we continuously learn new lessons from hand optimization and tuning for various backends.

As for your question in multi-stage scheduling. I think you already answered your own question, in a sense that tvm is intended to be used with graph level IR like nnvm, which gives you graph information and libraries like TOPI will make this problem easier

I see what you mean, if the group number is regular(e.g. same) I think it still makes sense to merge them into a grouped version of op(although you also have group wise scale shift).

If group numbers or other configurations are not the same, maybe it makes sense to optimize each kernel separately and launch them via multiple stream. Note that while most libraries optimizes for maximum perf of a single kernel. We could use TVM to get different kernels that might be slower when running a single op(utilizing fewer resources), but gives faster throughput when running those kernels concurrently
thanks for reply, I see, I can implem grouped version of op derectly, instead of auto merge the parallel ops by tvm
great, contribution to TOPI is more than welcomed!
I found it's okay `import tvm` if build without `LLVM-CONFIG` in `config.mk`. My LLVM verison is 4.0.1

Fixed. 

This problem is due to LLVM version. My OS is Ubuntu 16.04 64bit, but I downloaded an LLVM 4.0.1 for debian8 OS (LLVM 4.0.1 for debian8 doesn't support Ubuntu 16.04) previously. After replacing `clang+llvm-4.0.1-x86_64-linux-gnu-debian8.tar.xz` with `clang+llvm-4.0.0-x86_64-linux-gnu-ubuntu-16.04.tar.xz` and other installation operations, it's fixed.

I installed on another `x86_64-linux-gnu` desktop machine (named `cross-compile machine`) occurs same error as on my laptop (Ubuntu 16.04 64bit, **build`gcc xxx.c -lOpenCL` and execute OCL program smoothly**) : **segmentation fault (core dumped)** when executing `f = tvm.build(s, [A, B, C], target="opencl", target_host='llvm', name="myadd")` and etc. as below:

## Segmentation Fault on Local

I executed these commands using ipython:

```shell
In [1]: import tvm

In [2]: cl = tvm.cl(0)

In [3]: cl.device_id
Out[3]: 0

In [4]: cl.device_type
Out[4]: 4

In [5]: cl.sync.im_class
Out[5]: tvm._ffi.runtime_ctypes.TVMContext

In [6]: cl.sync
Out[6]: <bound method TVMContext.sync of opencl(0)>

In [7]: cl.STR2MASK
Out[7]: 
{'cl': 4,
 'cpu': 1,
 'cuda': 2,
 'gpu': 2,
 'metal': 8,
 'opencl': 4,
 'rocm': 10,
 'vpi': 9}

In [8]: cl.MASK2STR
Out[8]: {1: 'cpu', 2: 'gpu', 4: 'opencl', 8: 'metal', 9: 'vpi', 10: 'rocm'}

In [9]: cl.max_threads_per_block
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```
Besids `cl.max_threads_per_block`, the `cl.exist`, `cl.warp_size` triggered segmentation fault, too.

## My OpenCL Installation

### First way: from APT

I installed OpenCL on my laptop with commands below from [here](https://askubuntu.com/questions/850281/opencl-on-ubuntu-16-04-intel-sandy-bridge-cpu):
```shell
# Basic installation 
sudo apt install ocl-icd-libopencl1
sudo apt install opencl-headers
sudo apt install clinfo

# Needed to link and compile 
sudo apt install ocl-icd-opencl-dev

# For Intel GT core
sudo apt install beignet
```

Using above commands, I failed to intsalled OpenCL on `cross-compile machine` but successfully installed (use `clinfo` cmd. shows a lot of message) OpenCL by installation of [Intel OpenCL SDK](https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/opencl-drivers#latest_linux_SDK_release).

### Second Way: from Intel SDK

But I found some notes in [OpenCL™ Drivers and Runtimes for Intel® Architecture](https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/opencl-drivers#latest_linux_SDK_release) as below:

```
Installation has two parts:

- Intel® SDK for OpenCL™ Applications Package
- Driver and library(runtime) packages
```

I only installed first one (Intel® SDK for OpenCL™ Applications Package) on `cross-compile machine`, because I found that the second one (Driver and library(runtime) packages) doesn't support for Ubuntu 16.04 (ONLY support Ubuntu12.04 and 14.04, My laptop and `cross-compile machine` are both 16.04). Thus, I'm not sure whether the issue is about lacking of `Driver and library(runtime) packages` or not fully support intel device or others?

## Code on Local Machine
```python
import tvm 
import numpy as np
from tvm.contrib import rpc, util
 
debug = True
#target = "llvm -target=x86_64-linux-gnu"
#target = "llvm -target=aarch64-linux-gnu -mcpu=cortex-a72 -mattr=+neon"
target = "llvm"
 
def test_add(n=256):                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
    n = tvm.convert(n)
    A = tvm.placeholder((n,), name="A")
    B = tvm.placeholder((n,), name="B")
    C = tvm.compute(A.shape, lambda i: A[i]+B[i], name="C")
    print(type(C))
    s = tvm.create_schedule(C.op)
    print("create success")
 
    print(tvm.lower(s, [A, B, C], simple_mode=True))
 
    print("prepare to bind")
    bx, tx = s[C].split(C.op.axis[0], factor=64)
    s[C].bind(bx, tvm.thread_axis("blockIdx.x"))
    s[C].bind(tx, tvm.thread_axis("threadIdx.x"))
    print("bind success")
 
    if debug:
        print(tvm.lower(s, [A, B, C], simple_mode=True))
    # build
    print("prepare to build")
    f = tvm.build(s, [A, B, C], target="opencl", target_host=target, name="myadd")
    print("build success")
 
    ctx = remote.cl(0)
    print("ctx.device_id:" + str(ctx.device_id))
    print("ctx.device_type:" + str(ctx.device_type))
    print("ctx.max_threads_per_block:" + str(ctx.max_threads_per_block))
    print("ctx.exist:" + str(ctx.exist))
 
    dev_module = f.imported_modules[0]
    print("----- opencl code ------")
    print(dev_module.get_source())
 
    lib_name = "mylib.o"
    temp = util.tempdir()
    path = temp.relpath(lib_name)
    print("local saving...")
    f.save(path)
    print("remote uploading...")
    remote.upload(path)
    print("remote loading...")
    f = remote.load_module(lib_name)
    print("load module success on remote")
    a = tvm.nd.array(np.random.uniform(size=n).astype(A.dtype), ctx)
    b = tvm.nd.array(np.random.uniform(size=n).astype(B.dtype), ctx)
    c = tvm.nd.array(np.zeros(n, dtype=C.dtye), ctx)
 
    # remote
    time_f = f.time_evaluator("peak", ctx, number=20)
    cost = time_f(a, b, c)
 
    print("run success")
    np.testing.assert_allclose(c.asnumpy(), a.asnumpy() + b.asnumpy())
    print("check success")
    print("----- opencl code ------")
    print(dev_module.get_source())
 

remote = rpc.connect("192.168.1.56", 9090)
test_add()

```

I think graph IR is a better place to do auto-optimization of multiple-stages, because you will get more information about the whole pipeline, TOPI is just a temporary and practical solution in involving. 
For example,  the main idea in the paper of Halide 2016 is to partition the functions/stages in a large Halide program into groups (subprograms), and independently perform producer-consumer locality and input reuse locality transformations on these groups. 

About differences between Halide and TVM,  still confused to me.
1)"Schedule space“ you mentioned above,  what are they Hailde can't have? or will it be hard to extend these on Halide? 
2)why TVM cares about the ability of representation, if TVM is a back-end IR of whole stack， that's the question graph engines should care. 

Will there be a paper or something to elaborate your points above? I think this might be a often asked question with TVM growing. All of us might wanna know TVM is a new idea or just another wheel.

Thanks!

sure, graph ir have more information wrt to that and it is important. It was the approach we intended to take when we started nnvm. 

The main problem of graph ir is it is too far away from bare metal code, in a sense that specific generation rule need to be crafted for the space of explorations, and there are too many things left unspecified, unless all the rules get crafted for each operator (cost a lot of engineering for each device and possible rules). As we target more hardwares, you will find more problems, besides tiling, threading patterns and other issues.

TVM abstracts these patterns into schedule primitives. As all the lowering goes through TVM, it is crucial that the representation power of tvm is good enough so there is minimum work in graph ir. that is why topi is important here. A mixed approach with TOPI and graphir will results in an easier and useful solution.

We are working on papers and hopefully that will explain these issues more clear. In the meanwhile you are more than welcomed to try and explore the difference between tvm and other frameworks

I think you also raises an valuable point here, in a sense that graph ir is necessary to work together with the low level ir for the workload optimization, that is exactly the approach we are taking right now. With nnvm for the graph level stack and tvm/topi as tensor level stack.

Another thing to note is that while utilizing global information is important, it is actually not the only(maybe not even the biggest) problem here. After smart fusing or graph optimization, Everything is still capped by how much you can push on single kernel performance, so it is crucial to get the tensor ir's space of representation to get this part right, and it is orthogonal to benefit you can get from a graphir
Last two comments, and we can merge this in. Thanks for the work to make this happen

The things we need to do in whole stack
1) Coarse-grained operators optimization: operators/kernels/stages fusion and layout optimization, which are main issues XLA/NNVM, or other graph engines are trying to improve.
2) Fine-grained operators optimization: single kernel/across kernels performance,  on which tvm/halide focus.

So differences between halide and tvm, 
1)  halide is a tensor type dsl/IR，which don't have coarse-grained operators optimization, which are on graph engines, 
2) it might be very hard or limited to do these coarse-grained operators optimizations on tensor IR
3) also I guess auto-tuner on graph IR might be simpler and easier than on tensor.

It seems that Tvm itself might  be similar with Halide, but with graph ir, they will be much more powerful.
It makes more sense to me now.

Thanks.

Your comment on the importance of two level stack is good. On the other hand, the tvm tensor ir level alone also  contains quite a lot of innovations, mainly on the scheduling primitives and language(e.g. general recurrence support) to get more effective kernels on gpus and other hardwares, that is what I mean by representation power, as if the tensor level ir is not able to cover the space of good kernels, we will simply be bottle-necked by this part

```python
import tvm

a = [1, 0, 2, 3]
b = tvm.placeholder((4,), name="B")
c = tvm.compute((1,), lambda i: tvm.sum(*[v * b[i] for i, v in enumerate(a) if v]))
print(c.op.body)
```

I am not sure though if this will speedup computation. You might, however, this means fully unroll the dot product instead of using a loop, where you save in terms of compute but requires more instruction cache. You should try it out on your workload and I am curious to see what you could get :)
I printed out the naive schedule and it seems like this is what he is looking for. I am wondering why it costs more instruction cache though, once the code is generated at compile time? Thanks
Yeah, this is what I had in mind, thanks!! I'll update once I have results.

Many cases the reduction contains many levels, and can be done with for loops, in that way you get instruction cache reuse of loop body  because of the for loop. To do the sparse aware optimisation means  the need of fully unroll the loop, which increases the cost of instruction cache.

This might be less of the problem if the sparsity is structured, e.g. we are dense on one dimension and sparse on another, so we still get instruction reuse on the dense dimension
Interesting. I have learned a lot. Thank you!

cc @sxjscience
We can do compute at of index the second stage (choose index), and do the spatial split on the final stage(keep the reduction related split on the compute_argmax)
Currently, we do not support inlining of reduction with another stage. What we can do is to declare reduction in one stage and add in another.
Thanks a lot! I've solved this problem!
checkout https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm

@xqdan I totally agree with what you said on graph ir based solution and the original version of nnvm lacks core operator support for that(the comment seems to be deleted). we have been working on such a graph ir based solution, you can checkout https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm for the end to end compiler. Maybe we could move the discussion over to NNVM

This requires an update of the reduction operator implementation, which is doable but not supported so far. In general we find that zero initialization makes it easier to support reductions of multiple levels and tiling patterns. So brings more benefit than a peeled version of reduction. If you have evidence that the peeled version works better, we can work to bring this into tvm
the tutorial will indeed need a real cuda machine to run nvidia code. But you can also explore other targets like cpu or target supported by y9our machine
you can also directly browse the tutorials via http://docs.tvmlang.org/tutorials/index.html

You want to do make clean then make when build with llvm, because some of the pre-defined macros are not traced by makefile

Yes, I deleted the initial folder before trying this again. Not sure why I am getting this :/
In any case, the basic example should work without llvm, right?

This is mainly because the target_host is force set to "llvm". If we do not set the ```target_host```, it will redirect to "stackvm" that do not rely on LLVM.

However, we do need llvm for some advanced features, like storing the code into shared library.

You might need to update the target triple to match the A53/A72 arch, i.e. change line of ```-target=armv7l-none-linux-anueabihf``` to triple that matches the processor. You can do OpenCL deployment as long as your host server support opencl see https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/tests/python/unittest/test_runtime_rpc.py#L92
you want to make sure that LLVM_CONFIG is set properly, and after you rebuild, you reinstalled the library.
still the same question.

The tutorial needs to be able to compile on CI machine, which starts a local RPC server on x86. 
So the code path use_rasp=False is set up to do that. In real practice, you need to change use_rasp =True. 

If you are using arch64 architecture, the target triple needs to change a bit. (check out gcc --verbose on your board)
Since the tutorial causes a bit of your confusion, you are more than welcomed to send in a PR to update the explanation, so that  it is more clear to the future readers
make sure you set the LLVM_CONFIG to correct value, for example, if you get llvm5 from http://apt.llvm.org/ set it to be llvm-config-5.0

i'm sure the LLVM_CONFIG setted properly
`LLVM_CONFIG = llvm-config-4.0`
